msDesc.head:
Letter from
Maria Edgeworth
to John Gibson Lockhart, , Augst. 26h 47

div.p:
I cannot believe my ears!
- I do not believe my eyes!
I hear read from the
newspapers - I see in
the papers
married Charlotte Harriet
Jane Lockhart daughter of
J. G. Lockhart Esq --
Now I would rather
believe the most extraordina
=ry extraordinary , the most absurd thing
upon earth, that there
were two persons of the
name of Charlotte Jane
Lockhart and both the
daughter of one or two
J G Lockharts than be-
lieve believe than conceive that
my good kind friend
as I have always thought
-as I have always found him

could leave it to the news
paper Reporter to tell me
of his daughters marriage
- that daughter of whom
I have felt so sincerely fond
that Charlotte Lockhart
whom I fondly fancied
felt in return some little
liking for me - enough
at least to have been sure
that I must have been inte-
rested interested in knowing before
the common herd of an
event decisive of her happi
-ness happiness - yet I have not received
from her even the common
announcement of the event
which usually politeness
thinks due to a mere ac-
quaintance acquaintance - putting
all fondness or friendship
out of the question -

I have waited five whole
days with impatience' and
at last, not having one grain
of patience left, and, sick
at heart, with hope this
morning, & every mornings
post deferred I have
now poured out my griefs &
- perhaps my bile.

Pray write to me directly
my dear Mr. Lockhart and
give me some reason some
explanation; for I know
there is one - I never can
or will believe that a friend
who has alway been kind
and how has given me
such proofs of kindness preference, &
confidence as you have can
all at once turn short
about & become unkind with
out without any reason or motive

I hope you received my
last letter in reply to that
which you so very kindly
wrote me giving me an ac-
count account of the settlement of all
you affairs & the sale of the
Copy Rights of our Dear Sir
Walter and of your intention
to give an abridgement of
the Life Though the title is not given fully here, it is likely Edgeworth is referring to Lockhart's publication of the Memoirs of the Life of Sir Walter Scott - I hope - I trust
that you were not offended
if you did not receive my letter,
by the frankness, the boldness
with which I spoke of some
omissions I should desire
in your new Edn. edition

No - I cannot think you
would be angry seriously -
you might think me quite
wrong, but I am sure you
would feel my motive was right
and that I was urged perhaps
beyond propriety by my sincere

anxiety for your fame
your moral as well as
literary reputation - & his -

I cannot tell how it is
then - But I am sure you
will explain it to me if
you can - Or if there be
something which you can-
not cannot or do not like to tell
me - you will say so - And
that will be satisfactory as
to my selfish grievance -
But not at all as to the rest -

I most earnestly hope
that the marriage is all
you wish; & if that be so
just tell me so & with
pleasure I will swallow
my displeasure & be at
all events
div.closer:
Your old affectionate
friend
Maria Edgeworth
